messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Learning-based vs Model-free Adaptive Control of a MAV under Wind GustThis work was supported by ISblue project, Interdisciplinary graduate school for the blue planet (ANR-17-EURE-0015) and co-funded by a grant from the French government under the program ”Investissements d’Avenir”.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Navigation problems under unknown varying conditions are among the most important and well-studied problems in the control field. Classic model-based adaptive control methods can be applied only when a convenient model of the plant or environment is provided. Recent model-free adaptive control methods aim at removing this dependency by learning the physical characteristics of the plant and/or process directly from sensor feedback. Although there have been prior attempts at improving these techniques, it remains an open question as to whether it is possible to cope with real-world uncertainties in a control system that is fully based on either paradigm. We propose a conceptually simple learning-based approach composed of a full state feedback controller, tuned robustly by a deep reinforcement learning framework based on the Soft Actor-Critic algorithm. We compare it, in realistic simulations, to a model-free controller that uses the same deep reinforcement learning framework for the control of a micro aerial vehicle under wind gust. The results indicate the great potential of learning-based adaptive control methods in modern dynamical systems.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Adaptive Control and the NASA X-15-3 Flight Revisited",
        "Some fundamental control Theory vol. 2: Feedback linearization of single input nonlinear systems",
        "Robust and optimal control",
        "Sliding Modes in Control and Optimization",
        "Decision-making in a fuzzy environment",
        "Failures of adaptive control theory and their resolution",
        "The limits and potentials of deep learning for robotics",
        "An empirical investigation of the challenges of real-world reinforcement learning",
        "A comprehensive survey on safe reinforcement learning",
        "Learning-based adaptive control for nonlinear systems",
        "Soft actor-critic: Off-policy maximum entropy deep reinforcement learning with a stochastic actor",
        "Sim-to-Real Transfer with Incremental Environment Complexity for Reinforcement Learning of Depth-Based Robot Navigation",
        "Adaptive Control, second edition",
        "Adaptive Dual Control Theory and Applications",
        "Adaptive flight control: a pragmatic view",
        "New developements in the design of adaptive control systems",
        "Self-tuning regulators for a class of multivariable systems",
        "A simple dual control problem with an analytical solution",
        "Output controller for quadcopters with wind disturbance cancellation",
        "Adaptive control over quadcopter UAV under disturbances",
        "L1 adaptive control for Wind gust rejection in quad-rotor UAV wind turbine inspection",
        "L1 Adaptive Output Feedback Controller to Systems of Unknown Dimension",
        "Adaptive controller for systems with unknown time-varying parameters and disturbances in the presence of non-zero trajectory initialization error",
        "ℋ2subscriptℋ2\\mathcal{H}_{2} Optimized PID Control of Quad-Copter Platform with Wind Disturbance",
        "PID, LQR and LQR-PID on a quadcopter platform",
        "Real time optimization by Extremum Seeking control",
        "Extremum-Seeking Control and Applications: A Numerical Optimization-Based Approach",
        "Model-free Online Motion Adaptation for Optimal Range and Endurance of Multicopters",
        "Reinforcement Learning: An Introduction",
        "Dynamic Programming and Markov Processes",
        "High-Dimensional Continuous Control Using Generalized Advantage Estimation",
        "DroNet: Learning to Fly by Driving",
        "Self-Supervised Deep Reinforcement Learning with Generalized Computation Graphs for Robot Navigation",
        "SA-Net: Robust State-Action Recognition for Learning from Observations",
        "Neural Network Control Of Robot Manipulators And Non-Linear Systems",
        "Geometric Adaptive Control for a Quadrotor UAV with Wind Disturbance Rejection",
        "Geometric Adaptive Control with Neural Networks for a Quadrotor UAV in Wind fields",
        "Safe Online Learning Tracking Control for Quadrotors under Wind Disturbances",
        "Gaussian Processes for Machine Learning (GPML) Toolbox",
        "Design and use paradigms for Gazebo, an open-source multi-robot simulator",
        "ROS: an open-source Robot Operating System",
        "RotorS—A Modular Gazebo MAV Simulator Framework",
        "A hierarchical controller for miniature VTOL UAVs: Design and stability analysis using singular perturbation theory",
        "Soft Actor-Critic Algorithms and Applications",
        "Off-Policy Actor-Critic",
        "Double Q-learning",
        "Addressing Function Approximation Error in Actor-Critic Methods",
        "Adam: A Method for Stochastic Optimization",
        "Empirical Evaluation of Rectified Activations in Convolutional Network",
        "PyTorch: An Imperative Style, High-Performance Deep Learning Library",
        "Scalable parallel programming with CUDA",
        "Reinforcement learning for robots using neural networks",
        "Prioritized Experience Replay",
        "A Deeper Look at Experience Replay"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Learning-based vs Model-free Adaptive Control of a MAV under Wind GustThis work was supported by ISblue project, Interdisciplinary graduate school for the blue planet (ANR-17-EURE-0015) and co-funded by a grant from the French government under the program ”Investissements d’Avenir”., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
